ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Loved the field trips and would love to see the return of the internship component to the class!
This class was excellent

Unfortunately, it is my opinion that Roy Lee is simply too old to keep teaching effectively. He is not current on the material that he's teaching, and brings nothing new to the analysis of any reading that has been assigned. He is disorganized, and relies heavily on the TA to suggest readings and to keep him on track, both inside and outside of class. The readings were rarely assigned on time, and class discussion was almost non-existent because students learned, very early on, that they didn't have to do any work to get by during class. Roy is unable to encourage class discussion. The field trips of this class were it's only saving grace -- this course should, if it is offered in the future (which it shouldn't be), be entirely field-trip (or internship) oriented.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Fieldtrips and student presentations on topics they were interested in!
The field trips were awesome. Professor Lee prides himself on exposing his students to the inner workings of the UN.
The best aspect of this course was the field trip component.
The seminars and the field trips. I enjoyed the fact that there were plenty of opportunities for students to participate through presentations and discussions
The field trips were wonderful, though there should always be at least 3 meetings and students should NOT be given the choice about what time those meetings start.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Internships should be brought back into the class

The course lacks structure. It often felt like Professor Lee was rambling on about the same topic for multiple class sessions without any real objective. Similarly, student-led presentations were not organized in that people presented on topics that weren't necessarily related to what we were discussing in class.
In class lectures could be more structured and focused on topics.
More student discussion during the lecture period at the beginning of each class. The presentations were really useful for my learning, and seeing more of them would have been great.
The professor. See above.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, it was.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provides a great lens through which to view global diplomacy

This course provided an introduction to how the UN actually works and what considerations are most important in environmental diplomacy, which complemented my interest in international environmental policy and governance.
I'm a graduate student at the Jackson institute. My areas of concentration are diplomacy and foreign policy, this is why this course was a perfect fit for me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was looking for more diplomatic intro courses
I took this course to learn more about the specifics of environmental diplomacy and about the role of the UN.
Because I'm particularly interested in diplomatic negotiations.

I was hoping to learn about environmental diplomacy and to explore both some of the difficult decisionmaking processes as well as some of the skills one needs to be a diplomat. Unfortunately, other than during the field trips, the course taught me none of this.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes

Unfortunately, I came away from the course feeling pretty dissatisfied. While the topics we covered in class were interesting at times, the lack of structure didn't allow us to explore any one topic in depth.
No.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The field trips are awesome!!

Be aware that this isn't a conventional course and that there is no formal structure. Professor Lee is great to talk to about professional aspirations, but his lectures aren't the most fruitful. This class is definitely what you make of it, so make the most of the field trips.
Try to attend at least 2 field trips. They are extremely worth it.
